summary: Eye cancer is a rare disease that can affect all parts of the eye. It can be primary, starting within the eye (e.g., intraocular melanoma, lymphoma, retinoblastoma), or metastatic, spreading to the eye from other primary cancers (e.g., breast, lung). Eye cancers can be malignant or benign, with malignant forms often referred to as eye cancer. Treatment varies by type and advancement, including surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy.
causes: Metastasis from other primary cancers (e.g., breast cancer, lung cancer, prostate cancer, kidney cancer, thyroid cancer, skin cancer, colon cancer, blood cancer, bone marrow cancer)
risk_factors: Presence of a nevus (for melanoma development)
symptoms: Dark spot on iris or conjunctiva
Whitish or yellowish glow through the pupil (leukocoria)
Pressure effects on muscles and optic nerve
diagnosis: Evaluation of photographs for abnormal red eye reflex (e.g., white/yellow dot for retinoblastoma)
treatments: Exenteration (removal of eye and orbital contents, potentially eyelids)
Iridectomy (removal of part of the iris)
Iridocyclectomy (removal of iris and ciliary body muscle)
subtypes: Uveal Melanoma (Choroid Melanoma, Iris Melanoma, Ciliary Body Melanoma)
Primary Intraocular Lymphoma (Non-Hodgkin's, B-cell type, T-cell type)
